docs.lead_paragraph: GOT stress? Of course you do. And you are in very good (and very crowded) company. Competition is driving many people to work harder and run faster -- in both good and not-so-good economic times.

headline.main: Quick Lessons in the Fine Old Art of Unwinding

docs.lead_paragraph: LaWandra Williamson, a flight attendant for Trans World Airlines, was making the standard landing announcement on a flight from San Juan, P.R., to Kennedy International Airport. She asked passengers to remain seated until the captain had turned off the fasten-seat-belt sign. Despite her announcement, a passenger sitting near her reached up and opened an overhead storage bin. The passenger's baggage cart inside the bin had shifted during flight and came down on Ms. Williamson's head. Still speaking on the public address system when the cart hit her, she yelled, ''Oh my God, I'm hit,'' and then passed out.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Grounded by Amnesia, but Still Grounded in Family

docs.lead_paragraph: BEFORE he left his last job in the fall, Dr. Laszlo Fuzesi, a 45-year-old surgeon, had the surreal experience of being surrounded by 200 people who might not have been alive without him. Yet there they were, giving him a goodbye party at Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark, where Dr. Fuzesi had created the heart transplant program. ''It was quite emotional,'' he said, sitting cross-legged in his new office at Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, where he is leading the effort to build another transplant program. ''Heart patients are unique, I think. They are always so appreciative and there are so many great stories, you really get caught up in it. Besides, as their doctor you're allowed to do some pretty dramatic things.''

headline.main: From County Hospital To Regional Medical Center

docs.abstract: Article on recent efforts to turn Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, NY, into region's leading hospital outside New York City; Beth Israel Medical Center surgeon Dr Laszio Fuzesi, who has performed more than 250 heart transplants, has become involved in project as part of center's $6 million investment in new heart transplant facility; hospital's other recent accomplishments in gene therapy for heart patients, children's trauma treatment and treating of critically ill newborns described; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: State health officials and governors from both parties are lobbying the White House to revoke rules issued in the final hours of the Clinton administration that would provide a vast array of new rights to Medicaid patients in health maintenance organizations. The National Governors' Association, meeting here this weekend, and the National Association of State Medicaid Directors have convinced the new administration that the rules are flawed and should be reconsidered, with a new opportunity for public comment, federal officials said.

headline.main: States Ask Bush to Revoke Clinton's Medicaid Rules

docs.abstract: State health officials and governors from both parties lobby White House to revoke rules issued in final hours of Clinton administration that would provide vast array of new rights to Medicaid patients in health maintenance organizations; National Governors' Assn and National Assn of State Medicaid Directors said to convince Bush administration that rules would increase costs and impose immense new administrative burdens on states; states run Medicaid programs with varying combinations of federal, state and local money; rules specify procedures for patients to appeal denial of benefits; state officials say rules do not allow for differences in local health care markets (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Calling President Bush's effort to pass his tax cut the defining early battle of his presidency, a broad swath of interest groups and business lobbyists are mounting full-scale national campaigns, including grass-roots organizing and television advertisements, for or against the $1.6 trillion, 10-year measure. The organizing goes far beyond the old-fashioned ''Gucci Gulch'' lobbying for particular corporate tax breaks, and is drawing groups as far-flung as the Food Marketing Institute and the N.A.A.C.P. into the tax cut debate. The Congressional struggle could well turn into the kind of epic fight for public opinion that took place over President Bill Clinton's proposal for national health insurance.

headline.main: Interest Groups Are Gearing Up For High-Stakes Tax Cut Fight

docs.abstract: Interest groups and business lobbyists mount full-scale national campaigns for or against Pres Bush's $1.6 trillion, 10-year tax cut measure; epic fight for public opinion is looming; White House and Congressional Republicans are working closely with Washington's lobbyists and business associations as well as conservative groups to put pressure on Congress through national campaign; Pres Bush himself meets with business and trade group members gearing up to fight for passage of his tax cut; representatives of 150 liberal organizations hold their own strategy session; say Bush's proposed tax cuts are too large and unfair (M)
docs.snippet: Calling President Bush's effort to pass his tax cut the defining early battle of his presidency, a broad swath of interest groups and business lobbyists are mounting full-scale national campaigns, including grass-roots organizing and television...

docs.lead_paragraph: Some days, Theresa Sparks finds it an ordeal simply to walk out her door. How will she look? How will others see her? The same questions dog her everywhere. Entering a public restroom takes internal debate. Walking up to a makeup counter requires a stiff upper lip. Being a transsexual means facing stares every day. But Ms. Sparks, a 50-year-old environmental consultant who had a sex-change operation last year, has reason to believe that life will get easier -- if not soon, then someday, and if not for her, then for others like her. As the newest member of the San Francisco Human Rights Commission, and the first who is transgendered, Ms. Sparks said she planned to fight for the acceptance of people like her in the larger society.

headline.main: Another Minority Flexes Its Muscle in San Francisco

docs.abstract: Theresa Sparks, newest member of San Francisco Human Rights Commission, and first who is transgendered, says she plans to fight for acceptance of people like her in larger society; says she will fight job discrimination against transgenders; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Congressional Budget Office has sharply increased its estimates of spending on prescription drugs for the elderly, revisions that will make it more difficult for Congress to pay for drug benefits under Medicare. The new estimates, about one-third higher than those made last May, reflect new information about drugs that are in the pipeline and likely to come into use in the next decade.

headline.main: Budget Office's Estimates For Drug Spending Grow

docs.lead_paragraph: Three companies that operate most of the nation's managed care drug plans agreed yesterday to establish a joint system to make it easier for doctors to send prescriptions to pharmacies electronically or over the Internet. The three companies -- AdvancePCS, Express Scripts and the Merck-Medco unit of Merck & Company -- said the system would improve patient safety by reducing mistakes and misunderstandings. They said it would also save time and money for doctors, pharmacies and health plans.

headline.main: A Plan to Send Prescriptions Electronically

docs.abstract: AdvancePCS, Express Scripts and Merck-Medco unit of Merck & Co, which operate most of nation's managed care drug plans, agree to establish joint system to make it easier for doctors to send prescriptions to pharmacies electronically or over Internet; companies say system will improve patient safety by reducing mistakes and misunderstandings; new system is called RxHub; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With a determined tax cutter moving into the White House and Republicans still in charge on Capitol Hill, the stage seemed set early this year for Charls E. Walker to help lower the taxes paid by corporate America once again. The most enduring and perhaps best known of the scores of lobbyists who push tax cuts for business, Mr. Walker began making plans for a major effort to rally corporations around tax breaks that could be added to President Bush's $1.6 trillion tax reduction plan.

headline.main: Quiet on the Lobbying Front; Sudden Halt to Coalition's Bid for Corporate Tax Breaks

docs.abstract: Lobbyists for business were hoping for large tax breaks for corporations this year, but Charles E Walker, dean of group, cautions that now is not time to press for business tax cuts; Pres Bush has let it be known that any tax cuts will be aimed at individuals, not businesses; Walker has sought to reduce corporate taxes since 1978; graphs; charts; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The cardinal of New York's sprawling archdiocese has historically been one of the most important non-elected officials in a city that Pope John Paul II has called ''the capital of the world.'' Yesterday, in a sunlit ceremony before thousands of believers in Rome's St. Peter's Square, the pope presented scarlet caps or birettas to 44 new cardinals, including Edward Egan, the successor to Cardinal John O'Connor as New York City's premier Catholic leader. Cardinal Egan brings to this crucial job many powerful assets. He is a forceful and eloquent speaker who trained in theology and canon law and spent years in Rome as a church jurist. He is also skilled in the practical arts of managing a diverse and financially strapped archdiocese that stretches from Staten Island to the Catskills and serves more than 2.5 million Catholics. His fluency in Latin and his native English as well as Spanish, Italian and French works well in the city's diverse immigrant communities. The church in Rome has clearly chosen a gifted messenger as its newest cardinal for St. Patrick's Cathedral.
docs.abstract: Editorial tribute to New York Archbishop Edward Egan on his elevation to cardinal
